Instruction: In the file "AB12CD.pdf", on page 3, within the second rectangle, add a table with the following content: first row "Beam, Length, Material"; second row "B1, 5m, Steel"; third row "B2, 7m, Concrete"; set the font to "Arial" and font size to 12.
Groundtruth:
import fitz
import PDFbf

# File-level information
filepath = "AB12CD.pdf"
doc = fitz.open(filepath)

# Annotation extractor
annoextractor = PDFbf.extractanno(doc=doc)

# Page-level and order-level information
pagenumber = 2  # Page 3 (0-based index)
rectangleorder = 1  # Second rectangle (0-based index)

# Extracting target rectangle
rectangle, rfpoint = annoextractor.getclip_rfpoint(pagenumber=pagenumber, rectangleorder=rectangleorder)

# Table content
argument = dict(
    clip=rectangle,
    data=[["Beam", "Length", "Material"], ["B1", "5m", "Steel"], ["B2", "7m", "Concrete"]],
    font="Arial",
    fontsize=12
)

# Adding the table
table_adder = PDFbf.manipulate_table(
    doc=doc,
    pagenumber=pagenumber,
    clip=argument.get("clip"),
    data=argument.get("data"),
    font=argument.get("font"),
    fontsize=argument.get("fontsize")
)
doc = table_adder.addtable()

# Save the updated file
updated_file = filepath[:-4] + "_updated.pdf"
doc.save(updated_file)

    # In case the rectangle does not exist or index is out of range

import PDFbf

# File-level information
filepath = "KL34MN.pdf"
doc = fitz.open(filepath)

# Annotation extractor
annoextractor = PDFbf.extractanno(doc=doc)

# Page 3, Rectangle 1
pagenumber1 = 2  # Page 3 (0-based index)
rectangleorder1 = 0  # First rectangle (0-based index)

# Extracting target rectangle for Page 3, Rectangle 1
rectangle1, rfpoint1 = annoextractor.getclip_rfpoint(pagenumber=pagenumber1, rectangleorder=rectangleorder1)

# First table on Page 3, Rectangle 1
argument1 = dict(
    clip=rectangle1,
    data=[
        ["Schedule ID", "Task", "Duration"],
        ["S001", "Excavation", "10 days"],
        ["S002", "Foundation", "15 days"]
    ],
    arrange=[None, [80, 100, 60]],  # Column widths
    font="Arial",
    fontsize=10
)

# Adding the first table on Page 3, Rectangle 1
table_adder1 = PDFbf.manipulate_table(
    doc=doc,
    pagenumber=pagenumber1,
    clip=argument1.get("clip"),
    data=argument1.get("data"),
    arrange=argument1.get("arrange"),
    font=argument1.get("font"),
    fontsize=argument1.get("fontsize")
)
doc = table_adder1.addtable()

# Second table on Page 3, Rectangle 1
argument2 = dict(
    clip=rectangle1,
    data=[
        ["Resource", "Quantity", "Unit"],
        ["Cement", "200", "Bags"],
        ["Steel", "50", "Tons"]
    ],
    fontsize=11  # Font size
)

# Adding the second table on Page 3, Rectangle 1
table_adder2 = PDFbf.manipulate_table(
    doc=doc,
    pagenumber=pagenumber1,
    clip=argument2.get("clip"),
    data=argument2.get("data"),
    fontsize=argument2.get("fontsize")
)
doc = table_adder2.addtable()

# Page 7, Rectangle 1

rectangleorder2 = 0  # First rectangle (0-based index)

# First table on Page 7, Rectangle 1
argument3 = dict(
    clip=rectangle2,
    data=[
        ["Risk ID", "Description", "Mitigation"],
        ["R101", "Delayed Delivery", "Expedite Orders"],
        ["R102", "Bad Weather", "Contingency Plans"]
    ],
    arrange=[None, [70, 120, 100]],  # Column widths
    font="Times New Roman",
    fontsize=12
)

# Adding the first table on Page 7, Rectangle 1
table_adder3 = PDFbf.manipulate_table(
    doc=doc,
    pagenumber=pagenumber2,
    clip=argument3.get("clip"),
    data=argument3.get("data"),
    arrange=argument3.get("arrange"),
    font=argument3.get("font"),
    fontsize=argument3.get("fontsize")
)
doc = table_adder3.addtable()

# Second table on Page 7, Rectangle 1
argument4 = dict(
    clip=rectangle2,
    data=[
        ["Approval", "By", "Date"],
        ["Design", "Engineer", "15/05/2024"],
        ["Budget", "Manager", "20/05/2024"]
    ],
    arrange=[[80, 80, 80], None],  
    fontsize=10  # Font size

# Adding the second table on Page 7, Rectangle 1

import fitz
import PDFbf

# File-level information
filepath = "EF12GH.pdf"
doc = fitz.open(filepath)

# Annotation extractor
annoextractor = PDFbf.extractanno(doc=doc)

# Page-level and order-level information for Rectangle 4 on Page 4
pagenumber = 3  # Page 4 (0-based index)
rectangleorder = 3  # Fourth rectangle (0-based index)

# Extracting target rectangle
rectangle, rfpoint = annoextractor.getclip_rfpoint(pagenumber=pagenumber, rectangleorder=rectangleorder)

# First table content
argument1 = dict(
    clip=rectangle,
    data=[
        ["Zone", "Wind Speed", "Pressure"],
        ["Zone 1", "30 m/s", "0.5 kPa"],
        ["Zone 2", "40 m/s", "0.8 kPa"]
    ],
    arrange=[None, [70, 90, 70]]  # Specifying suitable column widths
)

# Adding the first table
table_adder1 = PDFbf.manipulate_table(
    doc=doc,
    pagenumber=pagenumber,
    clip=argument1.get("clip"),
    data=argument1.get("data"),
    arrange=argument1.get("arrange")
)
doc = table_adder1.addtable()

# Second table content
argument2 = dict(
    clip=rectangle,
    data=[
        ["Seismic Zone", "Factor"],
        ["Zone A", "0.10g"],
        ["Zone B", "0.20g"]
    ],
    arrange=[[30, 25, 25], None]  # Adjusting row heights as appropriate
)

# Adding the second table
table_adder2 = PDFbf.manipulate_table(
    doc=doc,
    pagenumber=pagenumber,
    clip=argument2.get("clip"),
    data=argument2.get("data"),
    arrange=argument2.get("arrange")
)
doc = table_adder2.addtable()

# Save the updated file
updated_file = filepath[:-4] + "_updated.pdf"
doc.save(updated_file)

doc = fitz.open(filepath)
annoextractor = PDFbf.extractanno(doc=doc)

# Page-level

# Order-level

try:
    rectangle, rfpoint = annoextractor.getclip_rfpoint(pagenumber=pagenumber, rectangleorder=rectangleorder)

    # Extract original table data

import fitz
import PDFbf

# Task 1
# File-level
filepath = "AB12LM.pdf"
doc = fitz.open(filepath)
annoextractor = PDFbf.extractanno(doc=doc)

# Page-level
pagenumber = 2  # page 3 corresponds to index 2
# Order-level
rectangleorder = 1  # second rectangle corresponds to index 1
try:
    rectangle, rfpoint = annoextractor.getclip_rfpoint(pagenumber=pagenumber, rectangleorder=rectangleorder)
except Exception as e:
    # If rectangle extraction fails due to invalid order or page, record missing order-level info
    missing_information = '''file-level: AB12LM.pdf, page-level: 3, order-level: missing (second rectangle not found), base-level: Replace the entire table with data, clear last column, use serif font and moderate size'''
    recorder = PDFbf.recorder(missing_information=missing_information)
    recorder.recording
else:
    # Base-level: Operation details are fully specified
    argument = {
        "clip": rectangle,
        "font": "serif",  # interpreted as standard serif font
        "fontsize": 10   # interpreted as moderate font size
    }

    # Extract original table
    table_extractor = PDFbf.extract_table(doc=doc, pagenumber=pagenumber, clip=argument["clip"])
    table_data = table_extractor.data

    # Prepare replacement data
    repdata = [["A", "B", "C"], ["D", "E", "F"], ["G", "H", "I"]]

    # Initialize table manipulator with formatting
    table_manipulator = PDFbf.manipulate_table(
        doc=doc,
        pagenumber=pagenumber,
        clip=argument["clip"],
        data=table_data,
        font=argument["font"],
        fontsize=argument["fontsize"]
    )

    # Replace entire table
    table_manipulator.data = table_manipulator.modifytable(repdata=repdata)

    # Clear the last column - need to determine number of columns dynamically
    if table_manipulator.data and len(table_manipulator.data) > 0:
        num_cols = max(len(row) for row in table_manipulator.data)
        table_manipulator.data = table_manipulator.emptytable(startcell=["all", num_cols])

    # Add updated table back to document
    doc = table_manipulator.addtable()

    # Save updated file
    updated_file = filepath[:-4] + "_updated.pdf"

# Task 1
# File-level
filepath = "KL90AS.pdf"
doc = fitz.open(filepath)
annoextractor = PDFbf.extractanno(doc=doc)

# Page-level
pagenumber = 3  # page 4 corresponds to index 3
# Order-level
rectangleorder = 3  # fourth rectangle corresponds to index 3

try:
    rectangle, rfpoint = annoextractor.getclip_rfpoint(pagenumber=pagenumber, rectangleorder=rectangleorder)
except Exception as e:
    # If rectangle extraction fails due to invalid order or page, record missing order-level
    missing_information = '''file-level: KL90AS.pdf, page-level: 4, order-level: 4, base-level: Replace columns 2 and 3 with: "Header1, Header2." Clear all other cells. Use an artistic font and a size that's formal. (incomplete)'''
    recorder = PDFbf.recorder(missing_information=missing_information)
    recorder.recording
else:
    # Base-level: Operation details
    # Extract original table
    table_extractor = PDFbf.extract_table(doc=doc, pagenumber=pagenumber, clip=rectangle)
    table_data = table_extractor.data

    # Argument collection: Some format attributes are vaguely specified
    argument_dict = {"clip": rectangle}
    
    # Font and fontsize are not concretely defined — "artistic font" and "formal size" are subjective
    # Do not assume values; skip specifying them if not clearly defined
    font_specified = None
    fontsize_specified = None
    align_specified = None  # Not mentioned
    borderwidth_specified = None  # Not mentioned

    table_manipulator = PDFbf.manipulate_table(
        doc=doc,
        pagenumber=pagenumber,
        clip=argument_dict["clip"],
        data=table_data,
        font=font_specified,
        fontsize=fontsize_specified,
        borderwidth=borderwidth_specified,
        align=align_specified
    )

    # Replace columns 2 and 3 (index 1 and 2) with new header data
    # Assuming the table has at least 3 columns and we are replacing entire column 2 and 3
    # We interpret "Replace columns 2 and 3" as replacing the header row in those columns, but instruction is ambiguous
    # However, since it says "Replace columns 2 and 3 with: 'Header1, Header2'", likely means set col2 = Header1, col3 = Header2
    # We assume this applies to the first row (header row)

    # Modify only the first row of columns 2 and 3
    if len(table_data) > 0:
        # Ensure there are at least 3 columns in the first row
        while len(table_data[0]) < 3:
            table_data[0] += [""] * (3 - len(table_data[0]))
        table_data[0][1] = "Header1"
        table_data[0][2] = "Header2"

        # Update only the target cells
        table_manipulator.data = table_data

        # Now clear all other cells (non-header or outside col2 and col3)
        # We interpret "Clear all other cells" as clearing all except the header row, or perhaps all except the replaced content?
        # But instruction says: "Replace columns 2 and 3 with..." and "Clear all other cells"
        # Most logical: keep only the new header in col2 and col3, clear everything else in the entire table

        # So we clear the entire table except the first row, second and third columns
        # First, clear the whole table
        table_manipulator.data = table_manipulator.emptytable()

        # Then re-insert only the two header values
        # But better: reconstruct the data with only those two cells filled
        new_data = []
        max_rows = len(table_data)
        max_cols = max(len(row) for row in table_data) if table_data else 3
        for r in range(max_rows):
            new_row = []
            for c in range(max_cols):
                if r == 0 and c == 1:
                    new_row.append("Header1")
                elif r == 0 and c == 2:
                    new_row.append("Header2")
                else:
                    new_row.append("")
            new_data.append(new_row)

        table_manipulator.data = new_data
    else:
        # If no data, create a minimal table with at least one row
        new_data = [["", "Header1", "Header2"]]
        table_manipulator.data = new_data

    # Add the updated table back
    doc = table_manipulator.addtable()

    # Save updated file
    updated_file = filepath[:-4] + "_updated.pdf"
    doc.save(updated_file)

import PDFbf


# Task 1
# File-level
filepath = "WX67MN.pdf"
doc = fitz.open(filepath)
annoextractor = PDFbf.extractanno(doc=doc)

# Page-level
pagenumber = 9  # page 10 corresponds to index 9
# Order-level
rectangleorder = 3  # fourth rectangle corresponds to index 3
try:
    rectangle, rfpoint = annoextractor.getclip_rfpoint(pagenumber=pagenumber, rectangleorder=rectangleorder)
except Exception as e:
    # In case the rectangle does not exist
    missing_information = '''file-level: WX67MN.pdf, page-level: 10, order-level: 4, base-level: Delete the first row. Replace rows 2 and 3. [incomplete]'''
    recorder = PDFbf.recorder(missing_information=missing_information)
    recorder.recording
else:
    # Base-level: Operations are specified but incomplete
    # Operation 1: Delete first row
    # Operation 2: Replace rows 2 and 3 — but no replacement data provided → incomplete

    argument = dict(clip=rectangle)
    table_extractor = PDFbf.extract_table(doc=doc, pagenumber=pagenumber, clip=argument["clip"])
    try:
        table_data = table_extractor.data
    except:
        # If table extraction fails, record as incomplete
        missing_information = '''file-level: WX67MN.pdf, page-level: 10, order-level: 4, base-level: Delete the first row. Replace rows 2 and 3. [incomplete]'''
        recorder = PDFbf.recorder(missing_information=missing_information)
        recorder.recording
    else:
        table_manipulator = PDFbf.manipulate_table(doc=doc, pagenumber=pagenumber, clip=argument["clip"], data=table_data)

        # Perform deletion of first row
        table_manipulator.data = table_manipulator.cuttable(delrow=[1])

        # Attempt to replace rows 2 and 3 — but repdata is missing in instruction
        # Since no replacement data is given, this part cannot be executed
        missing_information = '''file-level: WX67MN.pdf, page-level: 10, order-level: 4, base-level: Replace rows 2 and 3 [incomplete]'''
        recorder = PDFbf.recorder(missing_information=missing_information)
        recorder.recording

        # Save what we can (only deletion applied)
        doc = table_manipulator.addtable()

# Save updated file regardless
updatedfilepath = filepath[:-4] + "_updated.pdf"
doc.save(updatedfilepath)

# Task 1

    rectangle1, rfpoint1 = annoextractor.getclip_rfpoint(pagenumber=pagenumber1, rectangleorder=rectangleorder1)
    # Operation: Clear cells from row 2, col 1 to row 4, col 3
    argument1 = {"clip": rectangle1}
    table_extractor1 = PDFbf.extract_table(doc=doc, pagenumber=pagenumber1, clip=argument1["clip"])
    table_data1 = table_extractor1.data
    table_manipulator1 = PDFbf.manipulate_table(doc=doc, pagenumber=pagenumber1, clip=argument1["clip"], data=table_data1)
    table_manipulator1.data = table_manipulator1.emptytable(startcell=[2, 1], endcell=[4, 3])
    doc = table_manipulator1.addtable()
except Exception as e:
    # In case rectangle or page is invalid
    missing_information1 = '''file-level: File4.pdf, page-level: 7, order-level: 3, base-level: Clear the range of cells starting from row 2, column 1 to row 4, column 3 (incomplete - extraction failed)'''
    recorder1 = PDFbf.recorder(missing_information=missing_information1)
    recorder1.recording


# Task 2

    rectangle2, rfpoint2 = annoextractor.getclip_rfpoint(pagenumber=pagenumber2, rectangleorder=rectangleorder2)

    recorder2 = PDFbf.recorder(missing_information=missing_information2)
    recorder2.recording


# Apply formatting attributes to both operations (font, alignment, border width)

# Re-extract and update table on page 7 with formatting
try:

    missing_information = f'''file-level: {filepath}, page-level: {pagenumber + 1}, order-level: {rectangleorder + 1}, base-level: clear all cells starting from the 3rd row and 2nd column to the 5th row and 6th column. Use a casual font style with an indeterminate size. (incomplete - rectangle not found)'''
    recorder = PDFbf.recorder(missing_information=missing_information)
    recorder.recording
else:
    # Base-level: Operation details
    # Clear cells from [3,2] to [5,6]
    # Font is specified as "casual", but no exact mapping — assuming it means a common casual font like "Helvetica" or "Times"
    # However, font size is "indeterminate" → not specified → cannot set fontsize
    # So only apply font if valid; otherwise skip or warn

    argument = {"clip": rectangle}
    try:
        table_extractor = PDFbf.extract_table(doc=doc, pagenumber=pagenumber, clip=argument["clip"])
        table_data = table_extractor.data

        # Table extraction failed
        missing_information = f'''file-level: {filepath}, page-level: {pagenumber + 1}, order-level: {rectangleorder + 1}, base-level: clear all cells starting from the 3rd row and 2nd column to the 5th row and 6th column. Use a casual font style with an indeterminate size. (incomplete - table extraction failed)'''
        recorder = PDFbf.recorder(missing_information=missing_information)
        recorder.recording
    else:
        # Attempt to interpret "casual font" — map to a standard font name
        # Common casual fonts in PyMuPDF: "helv" (Helvetica), "cour" (Courier), "times"
        # Let's assume "casual" → "Helvetica" (common default)
        font = "helv"  # Approximation for "casual"
        # Font size is indeterminate → skip setting fontsize (let it remain unchanged)
        # Alignment and border width not specified → leave default

        table_manipulator = PDFbf.manipulate_table(
            doc=doc,
            pagenumber=pagenumber,
            clip=argument["clip"],
            data=table_data,
            font=font
            # fontsize omitted due to indeterminate value
        )

        # Perform clear operation
        table_manipulator.data = table_manipulator.emptytable(startcell=[3, 2], endcell=[5, 6])

        # Apply updated table
        doc = table_manipulator.addtable()

# Save updated file

    }

    table_data = table_extractor.data

    # Initialize manipulator with replacement data
    repdata = [["A", "B", "C"], ["D", "E", "F"], ["G", "H", "I"]]
    table_manipulator = PDFbf.manipulate_table(
        doc=doc,

        data=table_data,

else:

        data=table_data,

    )
